communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Sues for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Adem. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinsi) el Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: SHERI LAW IN EGYPT.
div.p: Pending the result of the labours of the Committee whose task is, subject to the sanction of the Council of Ministers, to Codify I into one system the four sections of the Sheri, I or religious law, a brief statement of what I these sections are will be of interest. The four I sects are the Hanafi, Shafi, Maliki, and Ham-1 beli. They profess to be, Sunnites, or orthodox I adherents to the traditions of the Koran, as I opposed to those whom they consider Shiya, I or heretics, to wit'ïho Persians. These sects I of Orthodoxy owe their rise to a difference of I opinion respecting points oÇréligion and law, I as held by the doctors after whom they are I named. The Turks believe in the Hanafi rite, I which is recognised as official by the Imperia! I Government. In Cairo, this sect is small in I comparison with the Shafi, who prevail also in I the Delta, Sharkieh, and Arabia. In tho Behe-11 ra the Maliki predominate, and the sect extends 11 to the Upper Nile, including the Nubians and I < Western Arabs.There is, too, a sprinkling of the I Maliki in the Delta itself. The fourth sect is, I like the Wahabis of Egypt, insignificant. All I sects agree as to the fourfold source of their I religion and law, which is . the Koran, the I traditions of Mohamed, tho concordance of his I - early disciples, and analogy. Thus, in view of I ' the harmony which unites tho four sects, the I labour of embodying their tenets into a code I will be both light and afford, in the eventof a I happy issue, general, satisfaction amongst the 1 adhorents to the four sects in Egypt. We must I anticipate somo faint echo of Turkish thunder I J at this disrespect Vf a rite which is official in I . the 1 Ottoman dominions, but we regard it as I j me proof the more to Tgrkey of the new order 11 >f things in Nile Land. j

div.head: NEW HEBRIDES CONVENTION. COLONIAL PREMIERS' PROTEST

div.p: The Premiers of the Commonwealth and I New Zealand have protested to Lord Elgin against the signing of the New Hebrides Con- ! vention, which they consider ùnduly favours I the Frenoh olaims at the expense of British I and Australian interests. (Reuter)

div.head: THE NEWFOUNDLAND FISHERIES. A SATISFACTORY COMPROMISE

div.p: In consideration ot the Americans agreeing not to nse purse and seines, the Newfound- I landers agree to refrain from fishing daring I the night time. Night fishing has been a fertile source of trouble owing to the men cutting one I another's nets. The compromise reduces the I possibility of friction to a minimum. (Reuter)

The Hungarian newspapers ascribe Count I Golochowski's resignation to the faot that he ad I had lost the confi-lence of the national re- I prssentatives beesnse he was too gpbservient U I to Germany to denounce the Triple Alliance I (Reuter)

An inquest has been held on the remains of Mr. Maofadyen. A verdiot of "nnsonnd mind" was returned. The railway .officials testified to finding the mangled body in the Tube tonnel. Death had possibly resulted from electocution. (Reuter)

div.head: New Cab Tariff.
div.p: The new cab tariff for Keneh town is to be issued in the course of this week.

div.head: Sale of Chizeh.
div.p: It is reported that Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel has sold his palace at Ghizeh for L.E. 400,000.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail from Europe, viâ Brindisi and Port Said, will be distributed at the G. P. O., Alexandria, at 9 p.m. to-day.

div.head: Khedivial Horticultural Society.
div.p: The chrysanthemum show, which was fixed for the 9th and 10th November by the Khedivial HorticulturalSociety, has been cancelled.

div.head: Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.
div.p: The Ministry of the Interior has recognised the establishment of a branch of the Cairo Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals at Beni Souef.

div.head: Khedivial Medical Society.
div.p: A meeting of the Khedivial Medical Society will be held on Saturday, November 3. Subjects for discussion and communications will be accepted by the secretary up to the 28th inst.

div.head: Druse and Bedouin.
div.p: A serious affray between Druses and Bedouins is reported to have occurred thirty miles from Damascus. There were heavy losses on both sides. The disorder was, however, hemmed in by the Turkish trroops.

div.head: H. M. S. Terrible.
div.p: Our Suez Correspondent reports that H.M.S. Terrible, which lost her starboard propeller and 8 feet of her tail shaft near Singapore, arrived at Suez yesterday afternoon with one propeller. She will go into drydock at Malta.

div.head: Egyptian Cotton for Japan.
div.p: Japan is ceasing to use Surat cotton, and is consuming a quantity of Egyptian. She is rapidly extending her cotton industry. During the last two years she has nearly doubled her number of looms, whilst twenty years ago the trade was almost nil. Employment is given to 85,000 persons.

div.head: New Army Hospital.
div.p: The Sirdar, Sir F. R. Wingate Pasba, and Major-General Bullock, G.O.C., accompanied by their respective staffs, have paid a visit to the new hospital of the Egyptian Army recently built at Koubbeh. The Sirdar congratulated Mr. Watson, the contractor, on the excellent arrangements of the building, which is thoroughly up-to-date.

div.head: Jardin Francais.
div.p: The entertainment provided in the theatre in the French Garden continues to attract large audiences nightly. After having renewed the engagement of Mr. "Gyp," the famous female impersonator, the management have secured the services of "Libre et Change," well- kown comedians from the El Dorado at Paris, who will make their débût this evening.

div.head: New Employment Registry.
div.p: Attention is drawn to the fact that the employment register of the British Chamber of Commerce, containing a large number of applications from men of all nationalities, is at the disposal of those requiring clerks, storekeepers, etc. The register may be consulted free of all charge at the offices of the Chamber, No. 6 Rue de l'Ancienne Bourse, Alexandria.

div.head: Egyptian Passenger Season.
div.p: For the Egyptian passenger season the P. and O. Company's October time-table contains particulars of their weekly departures from London, Marseilles, and Brindisi to Egypt and Eastern ports, with the rates of passage money. Details are also supplied of the Port Said-Cairo train service, and of the steamships by means of which the company's newly-instituted cargo service from Australia will be maintained.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: On the 20th and 21st October 25 vessels, of which 10 were northward and 15 southward bound, transited the canal, and paid for transit and passenger toll Fr. 645,511.48. Of these 12 were British, 5 German, 3 French, 1 Italian, 1 Dutch, 1 Norwegian, 1 Egyptian, and 1 Spanish. The total receipts since October 1 are Fr, 5,757,651.29 and during that time 213 vessels transited the Canal, 94 being northward, and 119 southward bound.

div.head: Sale of Gianaclis' Property.
div.p: As the result of lengthy negotiations, M. Nestor Gianaclis has decided to sell his property in Old Cairo for £122,000 to a group of financiers, in which the Improvements Corporation is interested. M. Gianaclis' old cigarette factory stood on this estate, which is 8,120 square metres on area. The new Gianaclis factory is to be at Shoubra, in the Palais Ciccolani, which has been completed renovated and converted into a model establishment.

div.head: BOTTLING THE JORDAN. PROGRESS OF AMERICAN SCHEME
div.p: Considerable interest is being taken in Palestine in the scheme of an American company to export the waters of the Jordan River to the United States to serve for baptismal and other religious purposes.

Colonel Nadaud, the president of the International River Jordan Water Company, has been at the Jordan for the last fortnight with a staff of 20 men, who are busily engaged in boiling, filtering, and disinfecting 60,000 kilos. (equalling thirty tons) of river water. The water is being placed in barrels of 600 kilos, capacity, and each barrel has to be thoroughly cleaned and steamed inside with boiling water and sods, then washed again with a disinfectant in order to kill what germs may lurk in the wood.

The greatest precautions are being taken to ensure the absolute purity of the water, which, I am assured by Colonel Nadaud, will reach the consumer in as pure a condition, if not as fresh, as spring water. He tells me that, if need be, it may be drunk by a baby with perfect safety.

Every barrel of the water will be sealed by the seal of the American Consul at Jerusalem, under his supervision at the Jordan, also under the supervision of a Turkish soldier, and of the Patriarch of Jerusalem, who will be represented by a monk sent here from St. John's Convent, near the Jordan. The seal of each barrel will only be broken as it is used in New York City, U.S.A., in a Government warehouse, by an authorized committee, and bottled only under their supervision.

The company's camp and working scene at the Jordan is a great and most unusual sight. Natives in charge of large camel caravans and tourists to the Jordan crowd around the camp at all hours to ascertain what it all means.

div.head: WHITE SLAVE TRADE. CONGRESS IN PARIS.
div.p: M. Fallières has received the members of the congress for the repression of the white slave traffic. The Egyptian delegate was presented by M. Berenger. (Havas)

div.head: A SUEZ PETITION.
div.p: A petition has been presented by the steamship agents and merchants of Suez, to Mr. A. Williams, Director of Customs, praying him to do what he can to induce the Government to dredge the creek leading to Suez. Everybody most sincerely hopes that Mr. Williams, who takes such an interest in the welfare of Suez, will succeed in persuading the authorities to dredge the creek, which at low tide is impassable to steam launches and lighters. Naturally this is a great drawback to the commerce of the town as well as a serious delay to shipping. The general opinion is that the creek, once dredged, would last for many years, and the work is not expected to entail any heavy expenditure.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive is spending the day on his estates at Mariout, whither he proceeded yesterday. On Friday evening he will give an "ftar" at Ras-el-Tin Palace to the notable native merchants of Alexandria.
His Highness will receive Lord Cromer in private audience at Ras-el-Tin Palace on Friday next.

div.head: MIXED TRIBUNALS
div.p: According to the estimates of the Ministry of Justice for 1907, two new judgeships are to be created in the Mixed Courts of Cairo and Alexandria. The vacancies will probably be filled by Swedish and Norwegian judges.
The Ministry of Justice has selected a Portuguese judge for the Mixed Court of Mansourab, and the appointment is expected to be confirmed by the Portuguese Government.
The Swedish judge at the Mansourah Mixed Court will be transferred shortly to the Court of Alexandria.
M. Antoniades, Counsellor in the Mixed Court of Appeal, Cairo, resigned his office yesterday.
M. de Bernardie, French Counsellor of the Cairo Mixed Court of Appeal, intends to resign shortly, and he will probably be replaced by M. Prunières, of the Cairo Mixed Court of 1st Instance.

div.head: MINISTRY OF FINANCE.
div.p: "La Réforme,'' in discussing the appointment of Chitty Bey to the Finance Ministry at Cairo, concludes as follows :—

Il nous semble seulement que la situation de M. Mitchell Innes, sous-secrétaire d'Etat aux finances, serait réduite à un tel point qu'il ne resterait plus rien à faire à ce haut fonctionnaire, sauf à se retirer ; la chose arrangerait, paral'-il, tout le monde daus le gonvernement et dans l'administration.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Creole Prince left Malta yesterday with passengers and general cargo, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Saturday.

div.head: THE SULTAN'S HEALTH. PROFESSOR BIER'S STATEMENT.
div.p: Professor Bier has left. He has declared that the Sultan is cured of the simple catarrh of the bladder from which he suffered. (H)

div.head: "ARE WE FANATICAL?" NATIVE PRESS OPINION.
div.p: Dealing with the subject of the alleged wave of fanaticism in Egypt, "Al Manar" says : -- The sympathy shown by Egypt towards Turkey in the Akaba and other affairs should not be considered as a purely religious fanaticism which may do harm to Christians. England and the other European nations admit that Turkey is Egypt's suzerain power ; but neither does Egypt wish to give up her independence for Turkey's sake, nor does Turkey ever think of doing away with that independence. Then Akaba is a very important point with regard to the Hedjaz Railway and to the Holy Places of Islam, and no one accepts to have his holy places governed by a man who professes another religion. Most of those who accuse us of fanaticism are the mouth-piece of diplomacy. Diplomacy is an unintelligible language : it is like the oracles which are understood only after the event has taken place. We are not diplomats, but we will tell the diplomats the following truth. We do not deny that we desire to be allowed to govern ourselves ; but this is only human. You cannot call that fanaticism. We do not take advantage of the troubles of foreign governments to attack them : the Mohamedans in Russia are not doing what the other inhabitants of the country are doing now. If you want us to live peacefully together and our interests to be reconciled it will be easy of attainment. We want justice, equity, etc. It was by these qualities that Islam conquered a large part of the world in less than a century. We see that you do not want to be our equals even in our own countries which we rule ourselves ; and you say that our religion teaches fanaticism.

The gist of the whole thing is that Islam is the most just of all religions ; that it was the Europeans who awoke the feeling of fanaticism in us ; that the Mohamedans educated in European schools are nearer to fanaticism than those educated at the Azhar ; that this fanaticism is not to be feared unless all the Christians I should unite together against Islam with the intention of wiping it out ; that the Sultan cannot order a general war except under these circumstances ; that the meaning of the word "fanaticism" as used by Sir E. Grey was that given above ; that this feeling awoke in the days of the Akaba affair, and that Lord Cromer feared troubles, so he took the necessary measures to avoid them ; that the Denishwai affair had nothing to do with fanaticism—it was due rather to the savageness of the villagers ; that England has inflicted a severe punishment in order to set an example to others ; that England has lost the sympathy of the people, which sympathy she might regain if everything goes on well now ; that the Egyptians are the least strict among the Mohamedans.

The Mohamedans may be divided into three categories: The Ulema, like the Azhar people, who study religion; those who study European sciences, and the common people. The first know the precepts of the Koran about dissenters living among us that they should be well treated and protected, etc. The only thing against this class of Mohamedans is that they are not sociable with the dissenters. The second category are as ignorant (as regards religion) as the common herd, but they are inclined to fanaticism for a political purpose ; fanaticism was fanned in them when they became acquainted with Europe's ambition and its opinion of Islam. The third category are the common people. They are simple and good-hearted. True, they believe that they ought to obey the Sultan, etc., but if any aggression is feared, they can be calmed by the ulema's sermons in the mosques. May Europe know that we are not fanatic, the man nearest to religion among us is the farthest away from fanaticism ; and the man nearest to fanaticism is he who is well acquainted with European civilisation.

div.head: TURKISH PAPER ON AKABA.
div.p: Anent the Akaba affair, the Turkish newspaper "Sanjak" states that this has been closed to the satisfaction of Great Britain. To Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha attaches all the blame for having raised a question which has strengthened British influence in Egypt and afforded the Occupation a means of securing a permanent hold therein.

Commenting on the above statement, the "Mokattam" points to the striking contrast between Turkey, the suzerain of Egypt, which does not deny the truth of the Egyptian Question, and the Egyptians, who state that Great Britain has no official or legal status in the Nile Valley.

div.head: EGYPT AND TURKEY.
div.p: In the last ''Revue de Paris" the editor concludes his article on Arabia. The liberation of Egypt, he writes, seems to be one of the aims of Turkish policy. The Sultan has never been reconciled to the English occupation, and though he has maintained territorial limits and political conditions, he is in the humour for wishing to change these conditions. If the Kaiser and the Sultan do not want war, the Akabah railway might in the hands of the English become the instrument of a more mischievous policy than Ottoman power. The Sultan under German protection, and the Ottoman peoples under the influence of England—that is the result of the Turkish Empire after fifteen years of Abdul Hamid's régime.

div.head: ENGLISH OPERA IN CAIRO. "THE RUNAWAY GIRL."
div.p: The Bandmann Opera Company gave their seoond performance of the season at the Khedivial Opera House, Cairo, last night with "A Runaway Girl," which was a great improvement on "Lady Madcap." The company had manifestly recovered from whatever fatigue their voyage had caused them. Miss Corlass had also recovered her voice, and the orchestra showed far more ease and unanimity. Miss Corlass, as the Runaway Girl, and Mr. Hany Cole, as Slipper, were the two brillant stars above all the rest. Mr. Cole kept his audience in fits of laughter, especially as "the Man from Cook's," and in his scene with the two brigands, the latter fulfilled all the traditions of Surrey side melodrama and had quite the proper command of their cloaks and daggers. Miss Leslie's Italian song was excellent, though a little hard here and there. Carmenita, Alice, and Lord and Lady Coodle were all good. Mr. Attwell, as Stanley, was also excellent. The piece contained many charming old favourites. The singing, of "Gurly Burly" was a great success for Mr. Cole, as was also "The Kind of Girl I hear about," and, of course, "Soldiers in the Park." The rendering of all these songs met with due appreciation. The "Goblin and Piccaninny" song is rather dragged in by the heels, but that always happens with the "musical comedies" of the present day. The music, too, is quite pretty. The only difficulty to be overcome is the stage itself. The chorus is small for so large a house, and the principals have not yet mastered tbe range of the theatre. But to conclude: if the other performances are on a par with "Tbe Runaway Girl" we may well be pleased, and with three such excellent performers as Miss Georgie Corlass, Mr. Attwell, and Mr. Cole, no piece could possibly fall flat.

div.head: NEW INDUSTRIAL SCHOOL.
div.p: The president of the Orwa Woska Society has been informed that the Ministry of Finance has decided to make a grant of L.E. 3,000 to the society for the Mohamed Ali School of Industries at Alexandria. The school, which is a magnificent building, was designed for by Hassabu Bey Mohamed, an active member of the committee, who has now been charged with the provision of machinery and is in communication with British firms for its supply.

The school was inspected the other day by Fakhry Pasha and Mr. Dunlop, who expressed themselves as greatly pleased with the building, and asked for a copy of the plans for the Ministry of Public Instruction.

div.head: GREEK LADY KILLED IN LONDON.
div.p: Mrs. Rodocanachi, a Greek lady, residing at 2, Clarendon-place, Hyde Park-square, London, was killed this day week by falling from her bed-room window to the area below, a distance of about 35 ft. She had been for some time in bad health, and was attended by a nurse.

About nine o'clock the latter left her for a few minutes, and almost immediately afterwards Mrs. Rodocanachi was found lying in her night attire in front of the house, with severe injuries to the head. She died very soon afterwards.

She was a widow, of about about 60 years of age, and had several daughters residing with her. She belonged to a wealthy Greek family, who have been established many years in England and are well-known in Egypt.

div.head: HELOUAN AS A HEALTH RESORT.
div.p: Still one more has been added to the many volumes written on Helouan as a health and pleasure resort, by Dr. H. Overton Hobson, with the title of "Helouan : An Egyptian Health Resort and How to Reach It." (Longmans, Green & Co., London.2s.6d.). The book is well-printed, illustrated with thirty-five excellent photographs, and its contents are both instructive and interesting. A long chapter is deservedly devoted to the baths, of which Dr. Hobson is medical director, and mineral waters of Helouan, which are of course the most prominent attractions of this desert city, and the general information given at the end of the book is most comprehensive. The now varied amusements of Helouan are well dealt with, and the book also contains some good descriptions of places of interest in and around the city.

div.head: ST. CYRIL OF ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: In the "Ravue d'Histoire Ecclésiastique" Père Joseph Mahé prints an article upon "Les Anathématismes de Saint Cyrille d'Alexandrie et les Evêques Orientaux du patriarchat d'Antioche." This essay is of much interest to students of the history of Egyptian Christianity. As is well known, this treatise of Cyril's was in opposition to the doctrines of Nestorius and was a polemical production of the Alexandrian theologian preliminary to the celebrated Church Council at Ephesus. The Anathemata were forwarded to Antioch to the prelates there and created such stirring literary effusions in reply, that Cyril hurriedly composed a series of Apologies in answer to the remonstrances addressed to him. This second treatise Father Mahé considers was composed and circulated previous to the Ephesus Council Meeting. He gives a new edition with ample commentary of Cyril's work.

div.head: EGYPTIAN EDUCATION. THE UNIVERSITY SCHEME.
div.p: (FROM A CORRESPONDENT).
(Conclusion.)

What the education reformers ask for is the study of "Arabic and European literature, sciences, philosophy, and history." Could not the Education Department provide this? The mistake the Government have made is to reduce the years in the Secondary school from three to two : students will not be prepared to enter the advanced secondary schools under three years. Let the Government first restore that year. Then, what is to be studied in the advanced Secondary school? Apparently the syllabus continues the same studies which were formerly included in the third year of the old Secondary school, and adds a certain number of subjects which are taught at present in the different Higher schools as introductory to the more professional subject there taught. The work of the Higher schools is lessened, or the subjects now taught in four years are spread over five. Apart from that there is little change ; and yet here is the material ready at hand to fill in some at least of the "gaps."

To revert to the former three years in the Secondary schools: give a Secondary certificate to all students who pass an examination at the end of that period; allow successful students either to enter the Government service, or proceed to the advanced Secondary school. The work in this new school should cover a period of not less than three years; in this period the subjects of study should be arranged in classes; certain subjects should be compulsory to all students, others should be voluntary, certain subjects being alternative, others according to the future intentions of the student. If the student intends to enter a particular higher school he should be obliged to take certain of the alternative subjects specially suited as preparatory to his future professional studies, but, if the student desires simply to enter the Government service, or to retire into private life, his choice should be lass restricted. At the end of the three years all successful students should receive a diploma in arts which would qualify them either to enter a higher professional school, or to apply for a more important post in the Government service than is open to a student who has only a Secondary certificate.

What of the new syllabus? What subjects are to be compulsory for all, and what alternative? "Arabic and European literature, sciences, philosophy, and history." There should at any rate be ample room for these. Arabic literature must be compulsory, the very backbone of the whole course of study. If English be a study, whether compulsory or alternative, attention should be concentrated on English literature rather than on grammar. An account of the Constitution of Egypt should certainly be given to all students, whether they intend to become doctors or merely dilettanti. It passes understanding why this subject is at present only taught to lawyers; such all educated persons in Egypt should know something about the constitution of the country; how otherwise are Egyptians to understand the constitutional changes foreshadowed in Lord Cromer's last Report? how otherwise are Egyptians to be prepared to take a larger share in the government of the State, as we are given to understand by the Native Press is their present desire? History is worth a place among the compulsory subjects; while among the voluntary subjects mathematics might alternate with a special period of history, such as that of Rome : and the natural sciences with French or Italian, or political economy, or political science. There are plenty of subjects to choose from, each with its own peculiar value, and what should make the task of the Government easier is the fact that living in the archives of the Ministry of Education is a syllabus prepared for just such a school as this; a syllabus which must have been living there now for some years; a syllabus prepared by an authority on education who realised that this "gap" existed and did his best to induce the Government to fill it.

The development of a higher school such as this would be the adoption of a system, well-understood in France and in Scotland, two countries in which education has always taken a prominent place in the minds of the people. In these countries no student may proceed to a professional study such as law, until he has obtained a diploma of arts. It may be said that students would hesitate to undertake so long a course of study; that to add yet three more years to the student career of a lawyer would prevent many young Egyptians entering the profession. But would this not be a blessing rather than otherwise? If the figures given by the "Gazette" are correct, no less than 100 new students entered the English section of the Law School and fifty the French section. Will there be work for a continuous output of one hundred and fifty qualified lawyers a year ? If students who have received the legal diploma of the School of Law, cannot find work, will the popularity of that school continue? Is there not a serious danger in increasing the supply so much beyond the probable demand? I speak more particularly of the School of Law since the figures have already been made public; the position of the other Professional Schools may be the same. But the School of Law, at present, occupies a special position; it is the highest school to which students naturally elect to go if they do not desire to enter any particular profession, but wish to continue their studies a stage beyond the present secondary schools. It is natural that this should be so, and the authorities recognise the fact by including a number

of what ate not strictly legal subjects in the course of studies of the School of Law ; subjects such as political eoonomy, political science, and the constitutional history of Egypt ; subjects which I have suggested should form a part of the curriculum of the advanced secondary school, or tbe school of arts as we may call it.

There does not seem any prima facie argument against the Government itself undertaking to fill this most serious "gap" in the education of the young Egyptian. Private enterprise is undoubtedly the best, and produces the best moral good ; but under present conditions, private enterprise has an almost impossible task to fulfil in trying to compete with government enterprise. Under the circumstances, the Government might give further proof of its broad-mindedness by carrying its education system just one step further, and thereby answering the appeal of a very influential circle of its Egyptian subjects, both Moslems and Christian. "Our people have came to the conclusion that its system of education is incomplete; that its limits are too narrow ; that it ends too soon !"

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Lord Cromer is coming to Alexandria from Cairo on Friday next to pay a visit to the Khedive.
Mazloum Pasha, Minister of Finance, hae returned to Egypt from his holiday.
Miralai Owen Bey and Naoum Bey Shukeir are due in Cairo at 11.30 this evening from Suez.

Judge Archer, of the Mixed Coart of 1st Instance, is leaving Alexandria for England at the end of the month in order to take up his new post as Counsellor to the Siamese Legation in London, in succeesion to Mr. F. Verney, the son of Sir Harry Verney, who has entered Parliament.
Lady Anne Blunt is leaving England on the 6th proxo. for Egypt.

Mr. C. C. James, the well-known Anglo- Indian sanitary engineer, is now in Cairo, and is energetically occupied with the drainage question of that city. Mr. James is the author of several volumes on Oriental drainage works.
Mr. and Mrs. Montagu Summers are staying at Shepheard's Hotel.
George Nungovich Bey and Mr. Constantine Meimarachi are arriving at Alexandria on Saturday next by the Hamburg-Amerioan S.S.
Oceana.

For the first time since the King ascended the throne he has stayed for two or three days at Moulton Paddocks with Sir Ernest Cassel. Sir Ernest Cassel has spent a very large sum of money on Moulton Paddocks since he purchased it from the late Lord Girard, who also in his time did a good deal for the place. The grounds are very delightful, with great shady trees close up to the house, but naturally it is more delightlful in summer than in autumn.

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE.
div.p: (Communication Officielle)
La Délégation Municipale s'est réunie le 23 octobre 1906 à 9 h. du soir sous la préûdenee de S.E. le Dr Sohiess Pacha.

Communication est donnée d'une lettre du 17 octobre 1906 du Ministère de l'Intérieur remettant les détails et renseignements que la Municipalité l'avait prié de vouloir bien lui fournir en vue du projet de construction de 8 ponts sur le canal Mahmoudieh.

Ces trois ponts coûteront L.E. 18,500 environ, sur lesquelles le Gouvernement a promis une contribution de L.E. 6000, le restant devant être supporté par la Municipalité et les Associations et Sociétés intéressées.
Cette lettre sera soumise à la Commission Municipale dans sa prochaine séance.
La Délégation renvoie à l'examen du Comité spécial chargé de la révision des allocations une demande du Khedivial Yacht Club tendant à majorer l'allocation qui lui est allouée.
Une séance de ce Comité, en vue de l'étude des allocations inscrites au budget et des demandes nouvelles, est fixée pour mercredi 31 octobre 1906 à 9 h. du soir.

La Délégation, sur la demande de propriétaires riverains, accepte de contribuer pour moitié dans la construction d'une canalisation devant desservir les immeubles de la rue Ragheb Pacha, et partant de cette rue pour déverser dans l'égout de la rue du ler Khédive.
M. Kuster ayant demandé le pavage d'une ruelle, conduisant à son dépôt, près de la rue dénommée Borham Pacha, sauf à prendre à sa charge la moitié de la dépense, la Délégation accepte.

Vu la note du service de la voirie demandant des instructions pour la continuation du pavage des rues suivant le programme établi au cours de l'exercice, la Délégation décide la réfection d'ores et déjà du pavage en dalles de la rue Caied Gohar ainsi que le complément de pavage des parties de rues non encore dallées depuis la rue Baïdawi jusqu'au Département des tabacs à la Douane.
Elle demandera également à la Commission un crédit supplémentaire de 2 à 3,000 L.E. pour permettre la continuation du pavage des rues portées au programme.

La Délégation autorise une dépense de L.E. 124 environ pour l'rétablissement de canalisations supplémentaires devant servir au déversement des eaux provenant des tanneries du Mex, sauf à récupérer des propriétaires la moitié de la dépense au fur et à mesure de leurs demandes d'embranchement.
La Délégation s'occupe de la question de l'insuffisance des carrières actuelles.

Sur rapport des services, une superficie de 30,000 m.c. des carrières municipales du Mex, réprésentant un cubage de 500,000 m. cubes pourrait être mis à la disposition des carriers, quantité qui serait de nature à satisfaire pour que'que temps aux besoius des entrepreneurs.

Cependant, il y aurait lieu d'envisager l'éventualité prochaine de l'épuisement des carrières disponibles pour les besoins des particuliers au Mex,et d'entamer les pourparlers déjà engagés avec l'administration des Chemins de fer pour l'établissement d'une ligne reliant la ville aux carrières de Dekeila, en vue de l'exploitation de celles-ci.
Conformément an désir du Ministère, l'administration est invitée à se mettre d'accord avec le service des bâtiments de l'Etat en vue du règlement de cette question.

Là Délégation prend connaissance des avis émis par le Comité des travaux publics an sujet de diverses questions soumises à son examen, et qui ont trait au sous-lotissement des parcelles des quais, dans la zone qui s'étend de la Poste au Victoria College, au terrain à réserver comme dépôt des pastèques près de la cale sèche, et enfin au mur de soutènement de l'hôpital indigène.

La Délégation charge l'Administration de procéder aux évaluations approximatives des expropriations nécessaires pour la continuation de l'élargissement de la rue Bab-el-Karasta, jusqu'à la rue Anastasi.

Elle prend connaissance d'une dépêche de la Municipalité de Berlin proposant comme candidat au poste d'Ingénieur en chef, Mr. Nier, ingénieur Municipal de la ville de Dresde. Cette lettre sera soumise à la Commission.

Sur la demande de Mr. Piot Bey, la Délégation propose à la Commission une dépense de L. E. 300 pour l'installation à l'abattoir d'une presse hydraulique destinée à réduire les contenus des estomacs et des intestins en un volume insignifiant, permettant de les brûler dans les chaudières et d'éviter ainsi toute contagion possible.
La séance est levée à 11 h. du soir

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Auiourd'hui à midi et demie.)

Un revirement complet s'est produit ce matin sur notre marché. La fermeté a repris le dessus avec tendance prononcée à la hausse sur toute la ligne. On attribue ce changement inattendu à ce que des positions se sont reportées en grand nombre pour fin novembre, ce qui écarte le danger d'une liquidation trop laborieuse pour fin octobre. Ajoutons que les re ports payés sont excessivement chers.

La reprise est générale, bien que les affaires demeurent limitées aux National Bank, Daïra, Cassa di Sconto, Nungovich Hotels, Delta Land, Nile Land et Estates. Sur nombre d'autres titres il y a demande assez active sans vendeurs. C'est ce qui explique la hausse.

De 27 1/16 la National Bank s'avance à 27 1/4, la Daïra de 16 11/16 à l6 7/8, la Béhéra de 39 1/4 à 39 1/2, la Cassa di Sconto de 237 1/2 et 232 1/2 à 238 1/4 et 233 1/4, les Nungovich Hotels de 18 à 18 5/16 la Nile Land de 16 à 16 1/4, la Khedivial Mail de 4 5/8 à 4 3/4, le Comptoir de 6 29/32 et 6 5/8 à 6 15/16 et 6 21/32 l'action et de 48 à 49 la part de fonda teur, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 5 5/l6 à 5 7/16.
Les Markets se relèvent de 25/6 à 26/3 acheteurs.
L'Anglo-American Nile, depuis longtemps stationnaire à 5 1/2, monte à 5 3/4 acheteurs.
De 3 25/32 la Delta Land remonte à 3 27/32
En grande faveur les actions Estates sont demandées à 2 1/8, soit 3/32 de hausse ; les parts de fondateur cotent 15 1/4-1/2.
L'Union Foncière est l'objet d'une demande suivie à 6 1/4, sans vendeurs.
Par contre, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier Egyptien recule de 336 à 335, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 35/9 à 35/3, la Building Lands de 4 7/8 à 4 3/4 et la Banque d'Orient de 134 1/2 à

Comme on le voit, la reprise est accentuée et l'animation de la séance peut se comparer à celle des plus beaux jours. Si les positions continuent à se reporter, la liquidation de fin courant passera sans encombre, ainsi que les précédentes.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny. NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, 23 Octobre.

Le taux de l'escompte libre à Lendres se maintient à 6 %. Hier, au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais est restéunvarié à 85 7/8 et l'Unifiée à 104. La National Bank a perdu 1/8 à 27. La Daïra a gagné 1/8 à 17. L'Agricole est demeurée inchangée à 9 7/8, de même que la Delta Light à 12.

A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a rétrogradé de 2 francs à 776. La Banque d'Athènes est restée stationnaire à 144. L'Em prunt russe 1906 a passé de 84.30 à 84 50 ; à Londres, il a haussé de 79 3/4 à 80 1/2.

Ici, la tenue d'ensemble du marché a été à peu près semblable à celle d'hier. On est resté dans le calme et dans l'expectative, en se maintenant plus ou moins ferme sur toute la cote. Les vues sont, généralement, optimistes ; mais encore attend-on une détente réelle de la tension monétaire pour s'orienter vers la re prise. A noter, comme trait carac éristitque de la matinée, un mouvement sur la Cassa di Sconto, déterminé par la rumeur que les petites difficultés concernant le doublement du capital de cette Banque auraient é é aplanies et qu'en outre le titre serait prochainement admis à la cote de Paris.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National a été traitée à 27 pour clôturer à 26 15/16. L'Agricole a molli à 9 3/4 et la Banque d'Athènes à 144-145. La Cassa di Sconto a atteint, au début de la séance, 242 pour revenir aussitôt après à 238 et clôturer à 237. Le Comptoir Financier a progressé à 6 15/16 7 l'action ancienne et 6 13/16 la nouvelle. La Banque d'Abyssinie est revenue à 5 5/8.

Le Crédit Foncier a été mieux tenu à 779-780. La Daïra a faibli à 16 11/16-3/4. La Béhéra est remontée à 39 3/4-40. La part de fondateur Immobilière a rétrogradé à 740. L'Enterprise and Development a fléchi à 12 5/8 ; la part de fondateur a, par contre, gagné 1 livre à 22 1/2. En bonne tendance, la-part de fondateur Wardan a passé de 8 1/16 à 8 3/4-9.

L'action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux a été négociée à 4 7/16-1/2 ; la part de fondateur a atteint 99-100 pour finir à 98. Les Improvements ont fait 5 15/16-6. L'action Allotment a avancé à 3 25/32 pour clôturer 3 3/4; la part de fondateur a haussé à 155 pour revenir à 148 et terminer à 151.

La Delta Light a faibli à 11 15/16. L'Héliopolis a été traité à 316-317. Les Automobiles se sont encore alourdies à 6 et leur part de fondateur à 11 3/4. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire se sont raffermies à 268-269. La Frigorifique a avancé à 4 13/16.
Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Nungovich se sont consolidés à 18 et les Egyptian à 7. Les Upper Egypt ont été recherchés à 5 3/8-7/18.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont été ramenés à 3 3/4-13 16. Les New Egyptian sont remontés à 33 sh. 6, Les Estates se sont raffermis à 2 1/16; leur part de fondateur a progressé à 15 1/8. Les Constructions ont été négociées à 1 1/2-9/16 et les Khedivial Mail à 35 sh. 6.
Nous détachons d'une lettre de Paris, en date du 16 Octobre, le passage suivant :

"La question de l'argent, ou plutôt du taux de l'argent, a été, la semaine dernière, par suite de la liquidation de quinzaine, un grand sujet à préoccupations pour les acheteurs désireux de se faire reporter et qui pouvaient craindre de voir les profits de leurs opérations entamés par le prix élevé des reports. Ces craintes ne se sont pas toutefois réalisées, et la liquidation s'est effectuée plus aisément qu'on le pensait. C'est que précisément les appréhensions qu'elle suscitait ont provoqué un grand nombre d'allègements, de telle sorte que, pour une grosse part, la liquidation s'est faite, pour ains: dire, par anticipation. Il n'en est pas moins exact de reconnaître que le taux de 4 et 4 1/2 environ, qui a été pratiqué hier pour les reports, est un peu plus élevé que le normal ; mais il n'est pas excessif et peut même passer pour modéré en regard de là tension monétaire actuelle.

La bonne tenue des actions du Crédit Foncier Egyptien est attribuée à une rumeur suivant laquelle le dividende de l'exercice en cours pourrait bien être sensiblement supé rieur à celui de l'année précédente."

Nous avons annoncé, la semaine dernière, que les actionnaires de la Société Anonyme Agricole et Industrielle d'Egypte sont convoqués en assemblée générale extraordinaire pour le 27 Novembre prochain au siège social, à Anvers, à l'effet de délibérer sur une augmentation du capital, avec émission au pair pour les anciens actionnaires, et sur la création d'obligations nouvelles.

Lé capital actions actuel de cette Société est de 10,000,000 de francs, représenté par 20,000 actions de Frs. 500. Le capital obligations s'élève à environ Fr. 23 000,000. Il y a 10,000 parts de fondateur, sans désignation de valeur, dont le prix actuel est de 1,215 francs. L'action est cotée 975 francs.

Les propriétés de la Société représentent une superficie de 41,668 feddans, dont le coût total est de L.E. 1,425,667. La balance du compte Profits et Pertes de l'exercice terminé le 31 Janvier 1906 s'élevait à L.E 104.031.

Suivant ses Statuts, la Société a été constituée pour exploiter les terres lui appartenant soit directement, soit en les affermant, et pour en revendre cheque année une partie après l'accomplissement des travaux d'amélioration, qui en augmentent considérablement la valeur.
Les opérations de revente ont porté, en 1905, sur 6,851 feddans, qui ont été vendus pour L E. 199,885, laissant un bénéfice de plus de 100% sur le prix de revient.
Depuis sa fondation, la Société a acheté 58,062 feddans pour L.E. 1,752,400 et revendu
16.976 feddans pour L.E. 784,485, ce qui a donné un bénéfice d'environ L E. 331,000.

Le conseil d'administration calcule que la valeur approximative des propriétés de la Société présente une plus value de L.E. 585,000 sur le prix de revient. Cette somme d'à peu près 15,000,000 de francs peut être considérée comme une réserve latente.

div.head: NEW EGYPTIAN NATIONALISM. MR. BLUNT'S VIEWS
div.p: Under this title Mr. Wilfrid Sciwen Blnnt indiots Lord Cromer's Egyptian policy in the "/□dependent Review." Lord Cromer's "veiled Protectorate," adopted as a compromise between Gladstone's policy of evacuation and Hartington's polioy of annexation, was never, hy its author, so the writer maintains, intended to promote the "prudent development of Egypt's institutions." He asserts- that after introducing many reforms widely advertised by Lord Milner and other agents in the Press, Lord Cromer this year assumed fall authority, and there came a coneequent resurreotion of Egyptian nationalism. Egypt is becoming con- vinoed of England's ill faith. All reforms are now understood as fattening the ox for the slaughter, or preparing Egypt for annexation. The dread of this on the part of Egyptians is legitimate and natural, Mr. Blunt thinks, and not to be set down to the fanatical excesses of Pan-Islamism.
Not Pan-lslamlsm.
Of Pan IalamiBm he claims to know more than any Englishman. He says :—

"I know its strength and its weakness. I know its fanatioal side, and I know its side of reform and progress. I know what its value is in Arabia, in India, at Constantinople, and in the Bahara no less than in Egypt. I have been for the last twenty five years on intimate terms with several of its chief exponents.

I sympathise with it, and in its Liberal sense I wish it well. My words, therefore, may have weight when I affirm that the current talk about it, as applied to the Egyptian f movement, of which at the present momentMnstapha Kamel is the most able advocate, is mere diplomatic mystification. There is next to no connection in reality between the fellahin of the Delta and the great fanatical brotherhood of the Sahara, the Senoussia, with which the French ate in difficulties farther west. Nor are the fellahin fanatically affeoted by any propaganda from Constantinople. In Egypt there is no hatred for religion's sake either towards Christians or Jews as snoh, or even race enmity, exceptât Alexandria, always a turbulent half European oity criminally inclined." Homo Rule for Egypt.

Mr. Blnnt affirm» that there is in^Egypt no love for the Saltan, but "the man in the j aws of the lion oalls out to the tiger for help, and in the grip of an English officialdom Egypt may well oast her eyes at times in the direc tion of Constantinople." Bnt -.—"What Mnsta- pha Kamel and the Nationalists want is Home Rule for Egypt under the Ottoman Crown. Absolute independence they would perhaps prefer, but they look at this for the present as too dangerous a freedom," Of Mustapha Pasha Kamel, Mr. Blunt bears the following testimony :—

"As for Mustapha Kamel himself I kn w him personally and I have read a good deal that he has published, and I have fur Ifimja high rcspcot as an honest and consistent patriot. He is also an astonishingly able man with great political insight and power of eloquent expression. He has been reproached with changing his political connections. But all his advooacy has had thesame basis, under changing conditions, that of gaining for his country friends ; that of trying to awake in Europe some sympathy with a liberal cause worthy of its assistance ; that of reminding Englishmen of their promises so publioly made of restoring 'Egypt to the Egyptians.' I am certain he is worthy of all the help English Radioal Members of Parliament can give him."

Annexation is the logical outoome of Lord Cromer's polioy, but that step we cannot take. What then oan we do 1 Mr. Blunt recommends ns to restore the self.govarnment in Egypt which we destroyed in 1882.We can retrace our steps,and begin again with Lord Dufferin's programme. Mr. Blunt says that we coold establish to-morrow a true native Government constitutionally endowed but we want a man like Sir William Wédderburn to begin-it.
Egyptian Sympathies for Turkey.
The "Tribune" devotes a leading article to to Mr. Blunt's article, from which we extract the following :—

Mr. Blunt, who oertainly knows the Egyptians as few Europeans do, assures ns that they are not fanatioal, and indeed there has been nothing in their history to arouse fanatioism. The movements which we have usually and perhaps hastily set down to fanatioism in Turkey have really been the reply of an alarmed Turkish minority to the threats of a rebellious Christian majority. They have sprung rather from fear and indignation than from religions excitement. In Egypt there was never a rebellious Christian element, and the Moslems never dreaded it uprising, Arabjjg movement was indeed direoted partly against the rather disreputable Levantine element in the Khedive's administration, but still more against the Turkish pashas. We do not think that the quotations from the baser sort of Arabio newspapers, foolish and violent tbongh they are, quite support tho charge of fanaticism ; and in any event he describes these papers as venal and-ephemeral, and makes no charge against the important Nationalist organ, "El Lewa." What these extracts do prove k however, that in the reoent Tabah dispute Egyptian sympathies were certainly with the Sultan. It is only by a series of leaps in reasoning that one could conolnde from this that the Egyptians - are religious fanatics so indifferent; alike to their own interests and to their prospects | of freedom as to wish to exchange an Eogli.h | occupation for direct Tarkish rule. The fact1 rather is that, finding Lord Cromer a resolute opponent of their dreams of self government, they took their revenge by sympathizing with I each of his opponents in turn. Mustapha Kamel I Pasha, for example, op to the Fashoda inoider t

and the entente tended to lean on France ; he now turns as naturally to Turkey.Jt is easy to censure ; it is harder to realise the desperation of patriots who, Je (pairing of the generosity of their conquerors, turn to any/foreign Power which may perohance assail us in our difficult and irregular position. The Irish have passed exactly the same phases of opinion ; they were always on the side of E igland's enemies, not always from any natnraL. sympathy, but rather by way of taking revenge for our denial of their rights. But however we explain these phases of sentiment and intrigue, the moral is clear. We oannot hope to conciliate the Egyptians save by redeeming our own procurer and conceding their proper olaims. We have done little for edooa tien in Egypt, and nothirg for the development of its political capacity. To create a more domccratio school system and a modern university—these ought to be the first steps. Let ns begin to reoonoile the talent, which undoubtedly exists among the younger generation, and we shhnld probably find that Mr. Blunt's ideal—the nationalisation of the oivil administration—is neither a remote nor a dangerous remedy.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: Colonel G. M. Mackenzie, Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, will vaoate the command of the 1st Battalion at Viotoria Barraoks, Belfast, on the 3rd November under the four years rule. Colonel Mackenzie began his military career in the 108th Madras Infantry—now the 2nd Battalion of the Inciakillings—in August, 1879, was attached to the Army Service Corps, 1888 91, w^s promoted oaptain in the former year, major in 1899, and lieutenant oolonel of the 1st Battanon, 3rd November, 1902. He served with the Istiattalion in the South African War duringijm operations in Natal, March-June, 1900, and commanded it for some time, and he commanded the 2nd Battalion in the closing stges of the campaign in the Transvaal and Orange Colony (mentioned in despatches. Queen's medal with four olasps). His successor has not yet been officially announced, but Major C. J. L. Davidson, S.O., second in command of the 2nd Bat, talion at Cairo, a well-known Derry gentleman will almost to a osrtaiuty get the command althoogh he has come under the age rules, and is liable to be retired before the vaoanoy ooonrs, He served with distinction in the Boer War with the 1st Battalion, and was desperately woanded at Pieter's Hill. His services earned him the D. S. 0., Queen's medal with five olasps, King's medal with two olasps.
Lieutenant H. C. Smith, 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers, recently c.t Cairo, has taken up the duties ot aide decamp to General Sir W.W.E.F. Forestier-Walker, Governor of Gibraltar.

Second Lieutenant W, F. Higginson, 2nd Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers', Fermoy, has been promoted lieutenant af'er the rather long period of nearly five years. He got his commission in December, 1901.

Gentleman Cadet G. Burnham, from the Royal Military College, has been appointed a second lieutenant in the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons, and will in the first instanoejoin the Reserve Squadron at Ballinoollig.
The Army Connoil has decided to abolish a number of small military stations where detachments of infantry and batteries of Royal Field Artillery are stationed. Ireland will suffer by this decision.

The War Office has established a system of interchanging officers between the British and Indian Armier and the military foroes of the British dominions beyond the seas.The Govern meut of tha Australian Commonwealth has taken full advantage of the opportunity to gain instruotidn for their officers. There is serving in Australia Brevet-Major E. C. Haag, of the 18th Hussars, a Staff College officer, in exchange tor Lieutenant-Colonel V.C.M. Sellheim C. Binow, attached to the Aldershot Army Cqrps, {or general instruo tion. Major AT.R. Lusoombo, of the Royal Australian Artillery, is serving with the Indian Army in exohange for Major C.V. Mainwaring, of the Indian Army, who is serving in Australia. The Dominion Government of Canada has Lieutenant P.B.R. Long Innés, of the Royal Australian Artillery, serving with the military foroes of Canada in exchange f or Lieutenant E Clairmonte, of the Royal Canadian Artillery, permanent foroes, who has been lent to the Australian Commonwealth military foroes by the Dominion Government of Canada. It is understood that the principle of exohanging between the home and Colonial foroes is under consideration as a farther means of forming conneoting links between the home forces and the composite parts of our Army beyond the seas.

The Diana, Captain R. Phipps Hornby, is presently on voyage home from the Mediterranean to pay off at Dec.mber on terminating her commission on that station. This orniser will be re commissioned for further service with l ord Charles Beresford's command by Captain H. S. Grant.
The battleship Hibernia is ^6 be ready for the pennant by the -last week of December preparatory to taking h6r place in the Atlantic Fleet as fl*g-hip of the second in command.

The armoured cruiser Eancas'er, Captain H. L. Health, serving with the Third Crniser Squadron attached to the Mediterranean F.eet, is to be sent to the China Station iu Dsoember, and her place will be taken by her sister cruiser Roxborongh, Captain Somerset A. G. Cal- thorpe, now attached to the Channel Fleet in the First Cruiser Squadron.

div.head: PITH OF THE PRESS. EXTRACTS FROM HOME PAPERS

div.p: Our Obsolete Imperial Organisation.

The unworkable character cf our present Imperial organization reoeives some fresh illustration almost every day. The events connected with the disastrous intrusion of the party politios of this country into the delioate and difficult situation in the new South Af-i- oan ooloniesare still fresh in the pnblio reoolleotior. Hardly less unfortunate was the result of the ignorant sentimentalist agitation of a section of the House of Commons which led the Imperial Government to attempt to interfere in an unjustifiab'e manner with the ordinary powers and prerogatives of the Natal Ministry. At the present moment we have the Newfoundland controversy, which brings out the same inherent diffi inities of the present system, though in a somewhat different aspect. Here we have one of the smallest self-governing parts of the Empire passing legislation which, though in form domestio, was in substance a direct aot of retaliation upon a foreign State, and was oaloulated to give rise to international complioations. This legislation was passed without apparently consulting either the Imperial Government or the Government of Canada, whose interests are vitally affeoted by the relations of the United States
to the British Empire. . .

The moral to be drawn from the whole inoident, in fact, as from all such incidents, is not so much that any one is to blame as that the existing system, workable enough as long as the Colonies were ontside the range of international politios, is entirely unsuited to modern conditions. Some system for effective intercommunication and continuous consultation on all questions affeoting inter-Imperial or foreign relations, and for making responsibility and power co extensive, needs to be devised and substituted for the present unworkable, regime at the earliest possible moment. ("Times.")
Mr. Balfour's Leadership.

' Those who are dissatisfied with the leadership of the late Prime Minister had better oross the floor of the House c f Commons, and we will wish them joy of their company and their company of them. The Conservative seotion of the party knows wall that the time is not far distant when they* may he called upon to form a new alliance, not less essentia! to the well-being ot the country than that which contributed so conspiouously to its prosperity from 1886 till 1906. The Socialists and anti-Sooialists are makiog a sohism in the Radioal ranks, Mr. Asquith has spoken just as strongly as the Master of Elibank and Mr. J. A. Pease upon the efforts of the Socialists to capture the party. Advanced Radicals, though by no means enamoured of the doctrines of collectivism, thiuk it prudent to reprobate tin sin, but to bribe the sinner with soft words. It is not any business of ours ; but a time will come when the Liberal defenders of civilised society will have to appeal to all sympathisers for support against a common foe, and it is imperative that when that appeal is made—and it may come sooner than is expected—there should be a solid, disciplined, and loyal Unionist party to respond. ("Telegraph.")
Efficiency must Precede Chettpness-

The fact is, that it is impossible to have a cheap Navy, We are to have economy by all means ; but the ODly method of obtaining a true economy is by the soientifio adaptation of means to ends. The object cf the British Nsvy admits of a perfectly simple statement. It is to ensnre and to maintain British supremacy upon the seas. That supremacy can only be ensured and maintained by the preservation of an absolute efficiency, and efficiency in men and ships oan only be seoured by a sea going fleet kept in constant praotics. We must have the best ships, the best men, the best weapons. Notone ot these things is cheap. But we must also obtain and hold a numerical superiority in sea-going ships ready for war. The new scheme directly diminishes that superiority. Nor have we only to consider the defence of these islands in this regard. The defence of the British Empire is the charge of the Navy ; and we are to provide against the possibility of attaok from more quarters than one, at places Separated from each other by thousands of miles It may be that no ex penditore which the nation could afford would adequately secure the Empire against all con- tirgenoies. But for that reason is it the more important that every ship we have should be kept efficient, and every man under training at sea. ("Standard.")
War Stores Sentences.

xThe Army will not relii-h Mr. Haldane's new fashioned method of virtually- substituting trial by the War Office for trial by court- martial in the oa*e of the effiters and non commissioned officers unfavourably reported on by the Stores Commission. It is not open to controversy that the official investigation brought to light wholesale corruption and stupidity, more or less permeati ng all grades except the highest, and it is quite right that those personally implicated should receive sharp punishcaeut. On that issue, the Army at large will be of one mind with Mr. Haldane and the Army Council. Bot bearing in mind bow-great was the varianoe in the evideuoe against individuals, justice required that everyone under suspicion of malpractices should be allowed a fair opportunity of proving his inno- oence. There is an unpleasant look of Star Chamber practice in their being tried oolleotive- ly by an impalpable tribunal sitting in oamera. ("Globe.")
''Ungracious Acquittals."
We are glad to see that some of the officers appear to he honourably acquitted, but the

issue of a graded list of degrees of punishment and the style of an administrative paper rather than of a judicial utteranoe makes the acquittals ungraoious, while it is not easy to discriminate between the degrees of blame implied in the punishments. Important questions of prinoqle and method are involved in this form of quasi- judioial administrative decision. ("Morning Post,")
Mr. Haldane Defended.

The public will endorse and approve the action taken by the Army Counoil in the case of the officers who were censured by the Royal Commission on War Stores in South Africa. Among those punished there msy be oases of individual hardship. But no War Minister could overlook the glaring faults disclosed by the Commission's rèport, or permit suoh serious offences to pass without vigorous action. Mr. Haldane has shown no precipitation, and has fully considered the facts. The number of those acquitted-«f all blame is satisfactorily large, but eleven officers have been oeusured ; five have been compulsorily retired ; and twelve officers and warrant officers have been discharged or retired Without pensions. It should be a useful lesson for the future."
("Daily Mai'.'')
Radical Criticism.

Mr: Haldane has oertainly not erred on the side of severity in his treatment of the officers and men oeusured in various degrees by the War Stores Commission. It must be remembered that the Commission estimated the "total preventible loss to the home taxpayers" at something between three quarters of a million and one million and a quarter. The loss was primarily due to the "smartness" and in some oases to the definitely fraudulent practices of some of the contraotors with whom the military had to deal. But it was also due partly to oorroption and"partly to 'irresponsibility, indifference, and want of intelligence" on the part cf the responsible officers, commissioned and non-commissioned. We must not underrate the severity of the punishment involved in retirement even under the most favourable conditions. But, allowing for this, we oannot butJeel that this million of money, more or less, changed hands, so fo say, with less friction than usually accompanies the improper transfer of a hundredth part of that som, ("Tribune.")

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. div.head: Notice. Sudan Government. Disposal of Building Sites at Port Sudan.
div.p: The Sudan Government will shortly dispose by Tender of about 400 Building Sites at Port Sudan.
The sites will be Leasehold held at Annual ' Rents on Building Lease for Eighty Years from 1st January, 1907. Rents will be payable only from date of acceptance of Tender.
The Lease will be Perpetually Renewable at Revised Rent3 fixed in default of Agreement by Arbitration dt the end of each term of years.
In fixing the revised rents the value of Buildings erected by Lessees will Not be regarded as a ground for Increase of Rent

Example : If a plot. is leased for a term of 80 years from 1st January 1907, then on the expiration of that term the Lessee will have a right (subject to observance of his convenant etc) to obtain a fresh lease for a further period of 80 years at a revised rent, and so on in' perpetuity. The revised rent will be calculated on the value the site would bear if it were vacant building lands.
Offers are invited of Premiums for the Purchase of the above mentioned leasehold sites.
All offers must be made by Tender, on the forms issued by the Sudan Government, and must be received at Khartoum not later than 1st January 1907.

Particûlars of the sites offered, Plan of the Town, Conditions of Tender and Sale, Form of Tender, specimen Form of Lease, etc., will on and after October 1st 1906 be open to inspection at the following places during the usual business hours :
Khartoum : *Office of Director of Agricul
ture and Lands (T) and Office of Governor of Khartoum Province.
Cairo : ^Office of Sudan Agent (T).
Port Sudan : Office of Inspector (Government Office) (T).
Suakin : Office of /Governor of Red Sea Province.
El Darner : Office of Governor of Berber Province.
Atbara : Office of Director cf RaUways.
Alexandria : Office of Mr. Macphérson Grant.
Port Said : Office of Dixon Bey, War Office Representative. ,
London : *Office of Col. Western, Broadway Chambers, Westminster and the Sudan Court, Imperial Institute.
Suez : Office of Capt., Falconer, War Office Representative.

For the convenience of intending purchasers the Conditions of Tender and Sale have been translated into Arabic and French and copies of the translations into either language will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. per copy at the Offices in the above list which are distinguished by a capital T.
Further information will lie obtainable after the publication of the above-mentioned documents on applieation in writing to The Diree t jr of Agriculture and Lands, Khartoum.
* Copies of the Documents will be obtainable after 1st Octobor 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. or 1 Shilling per copy at the Offices marked with an asterisk.

div.head: Government du Soudan. Concessions de Terrains a Batir a Port-Sudan
div.p: Le Gouvernement du Soudan va prochainement disposer, par voie d'adjudication d'environ 400 parcelles de terrains à bâtir à Port- Soudan.

Les dites parcelltes seront données à bail emphytéotique, pour une durée de 80 années à partir du 1er Janvier 1907, moyennant loyer annuel, à Charge pour le locataire de bâtir. Le, lojær ne sera payable qu'à partir de la date de l'apeptation de l'offre.
Les baux "seront renouvelables à perpétuité moyennant un loyer variable fiié à la fin de chaque terme, soit d'accord, soit par arbitrage.
En fixant* le nouveau loyer, la valeur des bâtiments élevés par le locataire ne sera pas considérée comme un motif d'àugmenta ion de loyer.

EXEMPLE : ' Si une parcelle <le terrain est louée pour une durée de 80 années à partir *du 1er Janvier 1907. Dans ce cas, à l'expiration de ce délai, le locataire aura un droit (à condition d'observer les conditions Æu bail) d'obtenir un nouveau bail pour une nouvelle période de 80 années, moyennant un loyer modifié, et ainsi à perpétuité. *
• La loyer modifié sera calculé sur la valeur du terrain, s'il était libre de construction.

Des offres sont demandées pour les baux emphytéotiques dont s'agit ; ces offres devront mentionner la prime que le soumissionaire est disposé à payer au comptant en sus des loyers annuels établis pour chacun dçs lots. La dite prime devra être payée en un seul versement à la signature du contrat de bail.
Toutes offre» doivent être faites par soumission, sur les formules dressées par le Gouvernement du Soudan, et doivent être reçues à Khartoum avant le 1er Janvier 1907.

Le détail des terrains offerts, le plan de la ville, les conditions de l'adjudication et de la concession, la fprmule de soumission, spécification du bail, seront à la disposition du Public* à partir du 1er Octobre 1906, aux lieux ci-après indiqués, durant les heures de bureau.
Khartoum*—Bureau du Directeur de l'Agriculture et des Terrains (T) et bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Khartoum.
Le' Caire* Bureau de l'agent du Gouvernement du Soudan (T).
Port-Soudan*:—Bureau de l'Inspecteur (Bureau du Gouvernement (T).
Souakim—Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province et de la Mer Rouge.
Wadi-Halfa—Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de B[alfa.
El-Damer—Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Berber. *
Atbara—Bureau du Directeur du Chemin de Fer.
Alexandrie—Bureau de Mr. Macphérson Grant.
Port-Saïd—Bureau de F. Dixon bey, Représentant du Ministère de la Guerre.
Londres—Bureau du Colonel Western, Broadway Chambers, Westminster et le Soudan Court, Imperial Institute.
Suez—pureau du Capitaine Falconer,- Représentant du Ministère de la Guerre.

Pour la commodité des acheteurs éventuels les conditions d'adjudication et fie concession ont été traduites en arabe et en français et des copiés de ces traductions, dans les/deux langues, peuvent être obtenues à partir du 1er Octobre 1906, moyennant payement de P.T. 5 par copie, aux bureaux mentionnés d ins la liste ci-dessus, qui sont suivis d'une lettre majuscule T.

Des informations supplémentaires peuvent être obtenues après publications des documents ci-dessus mentionnés, moyennant dehiande écrite adressée au Directeur dé l'Agriculture et des Terrains, à Khartoum.
* Aux bureaux marqués d'une astérisque, copies des documents pourront être obtenues àpartir du 12 Octobre 1906, moyennant payement de P.T. 5 ou un Bhelling par oopio.28497-2M
